title: Why infrastructure matters?

presenter: Nineta Hrastelj, EuCheMS - European Association for Chemical and Molecular Sciences

segmentation: So good afternoon everybody again and please, I do know that.
And I do realize that we are here today and this week because of online training.

But nevertheless, as we are physically all here, allow me first to start with some traditional way of teaching because I do like to use the boards very much and I was trying to release as carefully as possible since morning until now and I have at least a short list of keywords which are associated to what I will be.
Talking about now and I would like to put them on board first before I start with my presentation.
So as you can see, infrastructure has been mentioned several times today and to my surprise I might say so.
But then I'm pleased that I have chosen this topic so infrastructure is the first one.
Now the first question, can you read my handwriting or not really I will try to make the best so something that was mentioned in the first talk from Canada.
I think in this was.

Ignore so education.

We use catalysts in chemistry a lot.

And as you saw, I put on the 1st slide already my mentors.

Robert and Maria to.

The theme for my MC because by doing so you really made the team very complimentary complementary, so each of us has expertise in a different area and this was crucial for putting the course together.

With their expertise.
Becausw, I think we really made a nice progress.
All two of us.
Together then I got also and instructions are very nice instructions from the organizers saying we do not want to limit your creativity when you are drafting your presentation.
And I must say I really love this, but as you would see I more or less followed the proposed guidelines.
That's probably because we're all from Slovenia and have more or less the same logic behind.
And when it came to this, how to present myself, you know?
When you have written so many times CVS and stuff like this, it gets a little bit boring.
So now what should I write now again, OK again the same thing.
And then I realized actually that this hashtags and this kind of stuff can be very handy and useful.
Also for writing series and I group them in three different groups.
And they they are actually going more or less in through through the time how I started and what I'm doing now.
So I started as a researcher, young researcher in chemistry.
I did my PhD in chemistry.
I moved later on more in metrology which is signs of measurements which is linked to accreditation standardization.
I was heavily involved in setting up some education and training programs in this area, but then later on which is about more than a decade ago.
I moved mostly to management where I'm still now leadership.
I'm very much dealing with quality.
And during the last also ten years or so, I'm also involved in policy related issues, so I'm talking to policymakers mostly at the European level.
With the members of the European Parliament with the European Commission.

But as I'm from Slovenia, of course I'm also linked to the same things here, here in Slovenia, but as you know Europe is pretty small, so it's rather easy to fly backwards and forwards from Ljubljana to Brussels or to some other places.
So if you would like to access the course, the link is there, but we're not going.
To do this now?
We go on with the motivation.
Well, I'm I deeply believe that having a better knowledge about infrastructures, and so far I haven't yet.
Explained which kind of infrastructures I'm dealing with in my course, so this is not meant to be infrastructures of.
Motorways or trains or.
Planes or stuff like this?
Is this so called soft infrastructures?
And I have designed my course in this way that I have wisdom introductory chapter and then three different modules.
The first module is on education in Europe, so why education in Europe?
Because education in Europe is very different.
So it if you are studying in Slovenia, it's very different than if you are studying in the UK or if you are studying in Spain as we are building Europe as kind of a common space.

We can of course, now study wherever we want so it is becoming very important that young people in this case, when we are talking about studying, are aware of all the possibilities that they have in Europe.
On the other hand, side also for those who are coming outside Europe, of course also for them matter whether they would like to study in.
I don't know country A or country B or country C in Europe, so all this information is becoming extremely relevant.

Also because we do have a very nice student exchange program in Europe which is called Erasmus, which people can use either for traveling or moving inside Europe or going from Europe out or from outside, coming in and some other programs as well.
And this information is just not.
Collected on one spot.
So that was that was my idea for the first module, saying, well, I want to study in Europe, where do I find all the information?
Because actually all the information is available online, it is just that you have to know where to search for it and where to find reliable pieces of information.
That's one thing and then module 2 and module 3 which are not yet there but will be coming in the coming month.
This is content wise.
My area of expertise and 'cause I'm in this area already for more than 30 years.
I'm really getting frustrated.
Because it just.
Doesn't move on.

We keep explaining the same things again and again and again and again.

So the first one is mostly for students and then just recently I added within Paranthesis and their parents.

Quality infrastructure, as I mentioned, that's my Korea area of expertise, but this module is supposed to be done for citizens, so so it will be done in a way.
I think there is an example online in a way that.
Brings close to citizen one exactly.
Does it mean so that we don't talk in our own terminology, which is usually to high extent not understandable to citizen, but we say for instance look are you concerned about the quality of seawater?
And you say yes, I'm not sure whether it is safe to swim in this particular see and then, for instance, we're going to explain.

Why you shoot or you can have confidence in this particular case and what you have to check and where you have to look at it and stuff like this so there will be real life examples and research infrastructures.
This will mainly be focused on Europe.

It is about big research infrastructures because as you know I mean the big research and discoveries can only be done if you have really big research groups which are shared amongst many and not closed within a small.
In a small circle, and this is something which is being developed now within Horizon 2020.
For those who are more familiar with research programs in Europe and will continue to go on.
There was also questions saying, well, try to explain to which UNESCO Sustainable Development Goals this particular MC is related to, and I spend quite some thoughts on these because.
I was thinking OK. Basically it's education.
An education is linked to everything more or less.
Anyhow, like we heard today already many times.
But then I picked up some others.
Basically, the main criteria was what's going to be the content of the module 2 and module 3.
And then a little bit more about the cores and the module which is already there.
So that's a sentence from one of my editorials which are published two or three years ago.
So it's indeed when you talk about infrastructure, soft infrastructures, infrastructures usually are built in a hierarchical way.
So you do have a lot of these pyramids or whatever you want to talk.
You have to know about each pyramid, how to move inside.
You also have to know how to move between the pyramids.

And then, well, now with the social networks, you do have some horizontal layers here and there, but because of this it is even more important that you have knowledge, because now you must be in the position to distinguish what from these social networks is true and what is fake news or it is from the expert point of view, not not correct.
So this is how the module looks like.

Is that.

He said clearly you will see when you take yourself for the first time.

So all the rest is much better than the introductory video if you ask me.
